title: The forgotten world of Epirus: Greece Big Ride

The forgotten world of Epirus: Greece Big Ride

This is one of those facts that somehow evades the internet, which might mean it’s not a fact. But I refuse to accept that – a Greek man once told it to me on the island of Crete and he was tremendously old and had a shotgun in his car. It’s the explanation as to why Greek coffee is as it is.

Coffee, he said, has been around for an age, but it only came to Europe in the 1500s with the invading Ottoman Turks. Now, at this point in history the Ottoman Empire for the most part took Islam as its religion, while the Greeks were practising Orthodox Christianity (courtesy of the Byzantine Empire, aka, the Romans).

This religious clash gave rise to a class system wherein the ruling Turks were rich, the subjugated Greeks poor, hence the only way for the average Greek to get coffee was to take their Ottoman masters’ used grounds, dry them out, re-grind them extra fine, then rebrew.

The result is the siltier-than-the-Nile Ellinikos kafe I’m tentatively sipping amid the morning commuters in a cafe in Ioannina, dressed in full kit, helmet on the table, bike propped nearby, doing a terrible job of blending in with the locals.

I am at least sat with a genuine Greek, Pavlos, who works at the hotel I’m staying at as a sort of all-purpose guide. Pavlos will take you catamaran sailing, cliff jumping, wreck diving, ultrarunning, sea kayaking and beer drinking. He’s a bit like a friend for hire, which is nice as I’m here on my own, and although I’ve visited Greece a lot I’ve never been to this part before.

This is Epirus, a region in the northwest on the border with Albania. If they’ve encountered it at all, most travellers will only have looked unwittingly at Epirus from the island of Corfu, just off its coast. This is not a well-known holiday destination, but I think that’s a good thing.

Corfu sucks up the tourists, meaning that as much as any place you’ll find in Western Europe these days – and goodness knows travellers like me are the source of our own lament – Epirus is that horribly cliched word: authentic, a place that can offer adventure by two wheels.

Land of contradictions

We strike out north from Ioannina – or Yannena to its friends – the capital city of Epirus and, like many places in Greece, really, really old. The focal point of the city is its castle and vast walls, which ensnare an old town that is either charmingly rough or roughly charming, depending on your disposition.

The main reason Ioannina is here is Pamvotida, a huge lake once chockful of fish and potable water but now threatened by the presence of people and pollution.

Like all good lakes, Pamvotida enjoys some excellent stories, which Pavlos is happy to regale me with as we set off. Adulterers were drowned in its waters; armies marched over its frozen face; Russian sturgeon are bred here for caviar; in its centre sits the only inhabited island in Greece without a name.

And like all good lakes at 9am, Pamvotida is plate-smooth, reflecting and changing its hue as the sun gradually washes over the mountains behind. Greece, though, is a tricky customer. I can’t profess to have travelled far and wide, but the parts I’ve seen and love show a country that deals with two hands, the first serving beauty, the second proffering grit.

I think this sticks out to travellers like me because if anything’s even slightly nice or old in England (Scotland and Wales are different matters, much more egalitarian) it gets cordoned off and you have to pay to enter, but in Greece everything is just thrown together and you can park anywhere.

Craggy backbone

Greece seems imbued with a cheerful lawlessness, the kind that is at once freeing and responsible for the piles of rubbish laid at the feet of the sorts of street statues we’d try to put behind glass. Here, postcard views turn ruinous urban sprawl and back again in the blink of an eye. Here, the road we’re on peels away from rusting petrol stations and stray dogs and throws us with little warning into the mountains and the back of beyond.

Pavlos and I climb up and up a sun-scorched road, tarmac bleached almost as white as its lines and flanked by lizards skittering through wild thyme. At its crest is a monument Pavlos says belongs to one of Greece’s many wars, and a Hellenic flag, its primary blue and white folds lifting and falling in the breeze. I’ve long taken the blue of the Greek flag to be symbolic of the sea, but days like these make it seem twinned with the sky.

Soon we’re dropping down into increasingly cool air, a sign we’re heading for trees and water, and sure enough pines appear in earnest, thickening into forest as the road flattens and rolls over an ancient bridge and riffling water beneath. This is the Voidomatis River, says Pavlos, proudly adding that it’s the cleanest river in Europe. It certainly looks the part – every stone and fish and reed clearly visible even three metres up.

The Voidomatis marks one of many gateways into the Pindus Mountains, which run from over the border in Macedonia, via Albania and down to the tip of the Peloponnese in southern Greece. Hence the Pindus’s pet name, ‘The Spine of Greece’. Here lies Greece’s second highest mountain, Mount Smolikas, and Greece’s second longest gorge, the Vikos.

Eagle-eyed geographers will of course know the tallest mountain in Greece is Mount Olympus (2,918m), which is presumably why the gods chose it, and the longest gorge is the Samiria in Crete, which incidentally is where the bloke with the shotgun told me about the coffee.

At 2,637m, Smolikas would be a wonderful cycling summit were it paved, but instead we’ll have to make do with one of the highest roads in these parts, which runs from the bottom of the gorge to the villages of Papingo and Mikro.

I’d not heard of the Pindus before today, and when Pavlos tells me the upcoming climb won’t even reach 1,000m I can’t say I’m ready to be impressed. But as we wind our way ever higher I get the sense something quite special is happening.

The road flicks back and forth in neat switchbacks, and by the time we reach a lookout halfway up, the view is incredible. The road is neatly coiled at our feet and every which way I look mountains unfold to the sky.

We pedal on, the road straightening in a way that produces sharp inclines far steeper than the hairpins. Birds circle, eyeing us as we toil. Great limestone karsts punch holes through blankets of forest. Strokes of cloud brush the sky. We reach the crest and there, radiant in its glory, is a cat licking its bum in front of some wheelie bins.

Village life

Papingo is one of 46 villages in Epirus’s municipality of Zagori and arguably the most touristy, which in these parts means there are at least two cafes and one is open most Mondays.

Zagori villages are curious in that they managed to escape ransack by the invading Ottomans in the 15th century by negotiating a tax with their would-be new rulers.

This, says Pavlos, is the reason for the stone bridge we rode over at the foot of the gorge, and others we have seen since. The region, full of merchants given its proximity to the rest of Europe, was left to flourish, and the old wooden bridges that once connected the many villages over such difficult topography were replaced in stone by rich locals.

Descending back to the Voidomatis takes little effort and barely any more time, the monolithic peak of Tymphe and its exposed limestone peaks looking over us with a grey-purple stare familiar to anyone who has ridden in the Dolomites.

We retrace our tyre tracks a considerable way, back past the Greek flag, through roads lined with autumnal-turning trees, plummeting, climbing then dropping once more. Pavlos points out yet more stone bridges, which now seems to be our eye-spy way of passing the time.

Some are fairly intact, others more like rubble; all of them are precariously placed and head-scratchingly built. Such is the gradient of each arch or set of arches it seems impossible they could have been built nearly 300 years ago.

We pull over at what is by far the most impressive we’ve seen, helpfully signposted Kokkoros (they tend to be named after the person who built them), and Pavlos reveals the secret. The stones for the arches would be laid over great stacks of sandbags, piled up at times of the year when the rivers were dry.

Then, once the keystone was inserted, the sandbags would be sliced open and when the rivers returned the sand would flow away, leaving just the arch. Genius stuff.

Suffering in silence

Even at my most trying to be veggie, I don’t think I’ve ever managed a trip to Greece without being tempted into some barbecued lamb, and our late lunch stop in Kipoi – population: the guy on the grill, his mum and a dozen stray kittens – does nothing to buck the trend.

Perspiring bottles of Mythos keep coming, and by the time we gather ourselves to our bikes it feels like I’ve eaten a sheep and done a brewery tour. Pavlos and I gingerly roll off, a pair of intrepid kittens at our wheels, vainly hoping for more scraps.

To say the next 20km passes in near silence is no exaggeration. Save for a weary yassou aimed at a goatherd and his clanging flock, few words pass our tired lips. Heavy are the legs that stop for too long – a lesson I fail to learn every time and one now compounded by the uptick in the road.

On and on we wind, the individual trees to our right slowly merging into a vague, faraway mass of green as we gain height. A sharp descent is cruel, its relief turning quickly to discomfort as we have to regain the metres lost.

It’s strange to see the altitude gain only just pass 1,000m – we seem so much higher – but it’s an optical illusion; we’re surrounded by mountains with no real reference points, just the blind sensation of climbing. Eventually the road plateaus and pedalling returns to base levels, before gravity finally blesses us with freewheeling.

We cross a newer bridge built next to its forebear, ours prosaic in steel and concrete, the ancient Zagori a thing of stone-teetering splendour. But no sooner can we wonder at this latest architectural marvel than beauty segues back into the basic and the rough-hewn.

Houses with wrecks of farm vehicles and olive trees in their gardens populate the landscape; behind us the many undulations and colour grades of the Pindus morph into one lumpy, darkened form.

Before long we’re circumventing a highway on a cracked old road, an expanse of water just starting to unfold ahead. We skirt our way around the diminishing cliffside, finally able to see Lake Pamvotida again, and Yannena at its shores.

How we did it

Travel

Getting to Epirus is possible without flying by taking the Eurostar to France then the train, via Paris and Torino, to Bari in Italy. From there it’s a ferry crossing to Igoumenitsa, which is a 90-minute drive to the hotel on the coast where we were based. Total travel time is around 30 hours and costs start from around £330. Rome2rio.com is a great resource for planning such journeys. Alternatively, flights go regularly from London Stansted to Perveza airport, then it’s a 1 hour 25 minute drive to MarBella Elix.

Accommodation

The MarBella Elix (marbella.gr), near Perdika, truly earns every one of its five stars, with private infinity pools, a mini funicular to the beach and the widest array of food offerings you could think of. Full board costs from £185pn for a standard double; half board from £100; and rather wonderfully, free ice cream is served all day from the hotel’s beach cafe.

Thanks

Big thanks to Pavlos Zitakis from Explore the Outside (exploretheoutside.com), who planned our route and taught us about Greek masonry, and his business partner George, who drove our support vehicle with tireless cheer. Many thanks also to Periklis Gompakis, who hosted us at the MarBella Elix, and Isabelle Thomas, from Grifco PR (grifcopr.com), who planned our itinerary.
